text: Patient: Mmm, hmm. Doctor: Because I know you’ll never call me if you’re getting sick from the medicine. Patient: Oh! I’ll call! Doctor: No, you won’t! Patient: Yeah. I’ll call. Well, like I said, I started getting that pain in my hip last week, but I knew I was coming here today to see you, and I said I’ll just wait until I go in. But, yeah, it was getting kind of, it was startin’ to hurt. Doctor: Getting tough. Patient: Yeah. You remember when you did all that biopsy there. Right in this area, right here. Doctor: So, that tells me that the cancer is growing in there primarily. Patient: Mmm…hmmm. Doctor: Which may mean I’d have to do radiation to that area. Patient: Wowwww. Okay. Doctor: Because that is a joint that we have to put our weight on

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: You know the paperwork that we usually do. Patient: Okay. Doctor: The, it, the biggest side effect can be dropping of blood counts. Patient: So this will be the last chemo? Doctor: Yes. Patient: Okay. Doctor: For this particular one. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Then next time we’ll start the new one. Patient: Okay. text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: which is a combination sort of Tylenol with an opiate drug. Obviously, for any narcotics you take enough of it you don’t need it, you can get addicted. It’s just you know all the rage that’s going on Patient: Right. Doctor: but our cancer patients are in a different pool. You have cancer not treated, you’re in pain, we take narcotics. It’s at this moment the best option. Okay? Patient: Okay, yes. Doctor: So, don’t sit there and say wow, I haven’t taken it in five days, I can’t stand it anymore and now I’m gonna pop it. That’s not the life I want you to live. Patient: That’s what I do. Doctor: I know. Patient: Yes, I do. Doctor: Gee, you and every other guy I have in my practice which is why I say this. Patient: Oh, Okay. Doctor: Please just recognize that your quality of life will be so much better Patient: Okay.

text: Patient: In group one. Doctor: I don’t know if it’s group one; I heard group two. Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: Um. And then once those three have been treated, then, they’ll open up again for three more people. Patient: Okay. How often do you do that? Doctor: Uh, you have to be on drug for at least about, the third person should be on at least a month, and it all has to be deemed safe, and then the next three people. Patient: Oh, okay. Alright. Family Member: If it is, they take it to next level. Doctor: So, again, theoretically, if you stayed on treatment and then three months from now, he clearly showed a progression of disease then, there might be a window when the slot would be available. Patient: Okay. So, if I stay on this for three months, it’s most likely that, uh, let’s say it’s group two (for sake of argument) Doctor: Correct. For the current cohort, uh, oh, one slot left. text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: And um the person running the trial is a baseball fan so he has the Oriole trial. Doctor: We call it the Oriole trial. And um basically I will give this consent form and you can take it home to read through. Uh um, ORIOLE basically stands for for observation versus stereotactic radiation therapy for all metastatic prostate cancer. Um, the word means few. Like . And what does metastatic prostate cancer mean a few metastases, so it means few Patient: Um, hmm. Doctor: - you are eligible for this type of therapy for this trial. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: So in this trial, the ORIOLE part is defined as having three or fewer. Patient: So when you say three so what we determined so far is that it – it’s in one lymph node, so. Doctor: It’s possible that as part of this trial if you decide to look into it more – PAT; Um, hum. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: PSMA stands for prostate-specific membrane antigen. It’s a protein that sits on the cell membrane, on the surface of the cancer cell – Patient: Okay. Doctor: - and if you can imagine if you have radioactive molecule that binds which to your protein that’s found on the cell surface of your cancer cell and that can be used to um uh produce a picture like a light bulb, bright area of light, that we um – that we can sometimes pick up cancer that cannot be seen on a conventional CT scan or conventional bald scan . So it’s possible with that kind of scan we might find more than one spot.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
